This study used metal oxide-modified metal-organic frameworks to examine H2S catalytic oxidation selectivity. The findings revealed that the oxidation mechanisms and products differed between Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66. The dithionates were intermediate products of H2S oxidation on Al2O3/UiO-66, whereas the bisulfates were intermediate products on Fe2O3/UiO-66. Fe2O3/UiO-66 showed stronger surface oxidation activity than Al2O3/UiO-66. The formation of sulfate/SO2 was primarily attributable to surface oxygen, whereas elemental sulfur was primarily related to lattice oxygen. The product generation processes of H2S on Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 surfaces were as follows: H2S → HSO4 2− → SO2 → S for Fe2O3/UiO-66, while H2S → S2O4 2− → SO2 for Al2O3/UiO-66. H2O and surface oxygen have the potential to alter H2S adsorption on the catalyst surface. For Fe2O3, the conversion of H2S to SO2 involves both an oxidation process and a reduction process. For Al2O3, the conversion of H2S to SO2 includes two oxidation processes. Due to the oxidation step of S2O4 2− limiting the generation of SO2, the reduction process of SO2 was also hindered, which in turn restricted the production of S over Al2O3. Fe2O3 can achieve the oxidation and removal of H2S at lower reaction temperatures, while also creating elemental S. Graphical abstract The oxidation mechanism of H2S over Fe2O3 is as follows: H2S → H2S-(OO) → H2S-(OO)2 → H2S-(OO)3 → HSO4 2− → HSO3 → SO2 → S = O → S. The oxidation mechanism of H2S over Al2O3 is as follows: H2S → H2S-O → (HS)2 O → (HS)2O2 → (HS)2O3 → S2O4 2− → O-(SO)2 O → SOO-SO2 → SO2 → S = O → S. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selectivity Catalytic oxidation Hydrogen sulfide Reaction pathways Modified catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) primarily originates from reducible industrial tail gas and furnace gas, such as blast furnace gas, closed carbide furnace tail gas, and yellow phosphorus tail gas [1–3]. The presence of corrosive and poisonous gas contaminants might cause respiratory issues and equipment deterioration [4–6]. These tail gases contain a large amount of highly energetic gases, such as CO, which can be utilized as primary chemical raw materials [7,8]. However, the presence of H2S inhibits the usage of CO in tail gases. Therefore, it is important to properly remove H2S from reducible industrial tail gas and furnace gas. As far as H2S is concerned, it is typically removed through adsorption, absorption, and catalytic oxidation methods [9–11]. The catalytic oxidation approach has demonstrated excellent efficiency in eliminating H2S while maintaining low operating costs, making it the main method for H2S purification [12]. Currently, the most commonly used desulfurizers include metal oxides and metal-free based materials (e.g., nanocarbon, carbon nitride, boron nitride, etc.) [13–16]. Metal oxides, such as CuO, Fe2O3, Al2O3, TiO2, V2O5, exhibit higher oxidizing activity and superior thermal stability compared to metal-free based materials, are extensively utilized in the catalytic oxidation of H2S [17–21]. Cao et al. prepared the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst using the sol-gel method for the removal of H2S oxidation [22]. The catalyst achieved a high H2S removal efficiency of 95 %. The oxidation products included S, SO2, and H2SO4. Zheng et al. investigated the effect of oxygen vacancies on Fe-doped TiO2-x catalysts for H2S oxidation [17]. Surface oxygen vacancies can enhance the conversion of H2S and the selectivity towards elemental sulfur. In our previous works, the catalytic hydrolysis product of organic sulfur, H2S, was oxidized into S, SO2, and H2SO4 on Fe2O3 and Al2O3 [7,8]. It was attributed to the active sites containing oxygen. However, the oxidation products were different. As of now, the catalytic oxidation mechanisms of H2S over Fe2O3 and Al2O3 in the presence of water vapor are not clear. Thus, it is worthwhile to investigate. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials with unique performance advantages. These advantages include controllable pore size and modified pore surface, low density, and high specific surface area [23–26]. These advantages have led to a wide range of applications in many fields, including adsorption, photocatalysis, and thermal catalysis [27–29]. Currently, MOFs are frequently employed as adsorbents and catalyst carriers. MOFs as carriers typically exhibit excellent dispersion of loaded metals, particularly UiO-66. The physicochemical properties of MOFs can be effectively enhanced through surface modification and surface defect construction [30,31]. In this work, the metal oxides modified metal-organic frameworks (Fe2O3/UiO-66, Al2O3/UiO-66) catalysts were used for H2S oxidation. The influences of water vapor and oxygen-containing active sites were investigated. The surface characterizations of fresh and used catalysts were characterized by XPS, FTIR, XRD, in situ FTIR, TPD, and HAADF-STEM. Meanwhile, the detailed reaction path was studied through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Finally, the reaction mechanism was carried out. 2 Experimental and theoretical calculation methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zirconium chloride (ZrCl4), terephthalic acid (TPA), N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF), methanol (CH3OH), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3), aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3) were purchased from Aladdin and applied in this work. UiO-66 carrier was prepared by a previously reported method. Firstly, 0.76 g TPA and 1.06 g ZrCl4 were added into 50 mL DMF solution and stirred for 1 h until completely dissolved. Then, the mixed solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 150 °C for 24 h. Next, the autoclave was naturally cooled down to room temperature. Then, the solution was centrifuged and the solid was washed 3 times with DMF and CH3OH respectively. Next, the solid was dried in a drying box at 100 °C for 12 h. The metal oxide-modified UiO-66 catalysts were prepared by the sol-gel method. Firstly, 5 %(wt) metal nitrate (Fe(NO3)3 or Al(NO3)3) and UiO-66 were added into deionized water and stirred for 3 h. Then, the mixed solution is dried by rotary evaporation to obtain a solid. Next, the solid was calcined at 300 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Finally, the material was cooled down to room temperature and designated as Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66. 2.2 Catalysts characterization X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were carried out by using Al Ka radiation on an ESCALAB 250 spectrometer, with energy of Al target and power 200 W. FTIR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer in the 4000∼400 cm–1 wavenumber range using the KBr pellet technique. In situ, FTIR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer. CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD experiments were performed on a Belcat Auto Chem apparatus. XRD patterns were collected using a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray apparatus. HAADF-STEM images and EDS Mapping were achieved using the FEI Talos F200x apparatus. Raman spectra were collected using a Renishaw inVia micro-Raman spectrometer, which was equipped with a 532 nm laser diode. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was employed to determine the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution using a Quantachrome surface area analyzer. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The schematic diagram of the reactor set-up is presented in Fig. S1. The catalytic activity tests were performed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (6 mm inner diameter × 129 mm length) at 100∼350 °C. H2S from the gas cylinder (0.2 % H2S in N2) was diluted with N2 (99.999 %) to achieve the desired concentration (H2S: 1000 ppm). 0.1 g catalyst was placed in the reactor and the mixed gas passed through the reactor with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 mL/g/h. Water vapor was introduced through a water saturation system. 8 °C water was chosen for this work. Concentrations of H2S and SO2 were analyzed using FULI 9790 II gas chromatography. 2.4 DFT calculation method The calculation work was performed using the Dmol3 program in Materials Studio 2017, which included the calculation of reaction energy, geometric structure, and reaction pathway [32,33]. The calculation method and calculation parameters were based on our previous work [34–36]. DFT-D correction and spin-polarized settings were used in all calculations. The Fe2O3 (001) and Al2O3 (001) surfaces with a p(2 × 2) supercell were used in the calculation work. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Selectivity of hydrogen sulfide catalytic oxidation The catalytic efficiency of H2S over Al2O3/UiO-66 and Fe2O3/UiO-66 was investigated. The experimental results were shown in Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 1, Fe2O3/UiO-66 exhibited a 100 % H2S removal rate at 150∼250 °C and 86.09 % at 100 °C without the presence of water vapor. Meanwhile, the yield of SO2 increased as the reaction temperature increased. It indicates that high temperature promotes the oxidation of H2S. After introducing H2O, there was no significant change in the H2S removal rate and SO2 yield, except at 250 °C. Combined with the stability experimental results in Fig. 2, the introduction of H2O prolonged the time of 100 % H2S removal efficiency and decreased the yield of SO2 at 200 °C and 250 °C. This can be attributed to the dissociation of H2O and the interaction between sulfur-containing oxidation products and H2O. Therefore, a temperature of 250 °C was found to be suitable for the oxidation of H2S over Fe2O3/UiO-66. In this study, the maximum removal rate of H2S using an Al2O3/UiO-66 catalyst was only reach 73.01 % at 350 °C. This limited efficiency could be attributed to the absence of additional O2, which affects the H2S removal process. As shown in Fig. 1, when compared to Fe2O3/UiO-66 at 250 °C, Al2O3/UiO-66 at 350 °C exhibited a lower H2S removal rate and a lower SO2 yield. The desulfurization activities on pure Fe2O3 and Al2O3 are presented and illustrated in Fig. S2. As illustrated in Fig. S2, the highest H2S removals of pure Fe2O3 and Al2O3 were 93.5 % and 28.3 %, respectively. This evidence indicates that pure Fe2O3 and Al2O3 predominantly exhibited catalytic oxidation effects. This substantiates the assertion that UiO-66, as a carrier, provides adsorption sites for the catalytic oxidative removal of H2S. Moreover, the results demonstrated that pure Fe2O3 exhibited higher H2S removal and SO2 yield compared to pure Al2O3. This suggests that Fe2O3 has stronger catalytic activity, making it a more suitable catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of H2S. Furthermore, according to Fig. S3, there were obvious yellow substances generated at the outlet of the reaction tube when Fe2O3/UiO-66 was used as a catalyst. On the contrary, no substance was found at the outlet of the reaction tube when Al2O3/UiO-66 was used as a catalyst. It was indicated that the oxidation mechanisms and products differed between Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66. This difference was attributed to the surface characteristics of oxygen-containing species, including the origin of the oxidation group and the activity of metal oxidation. Therefore, the different surface oxidation characteristics of Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 were investigated. 3.2 FTIR characterization and Raman results over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 To investigate the differences in the oxidation process between Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66, FTIR measurements were conducted and the results are presented in Fig. 3 . As depicted in Fig. 3, the presence of S2O4 2− functional groups was observed on the surface of the used Al2O3/UiO-66 [37]. It was indicated that dithionates were the intermediate products of H2S oxidation over Al2O3/UiO-66. Therefore, H2S was first oxidized into dithionates and then further oxidized into SO2. Unlike Al2O3/UiO-66, the Fe2O3/UiO-66 material exhibited the presence of HSO4 2− functional groups appearing on its surface [38]. It was indicated that bisulfates were the intermediate products of H2S oxidation over Fe2O3/UiO-66. Therefore, H2S was first oxidized into bisulfates and then reduced into SO2. The results above proved that the surface oxidation activity of Fe2O3/UiO-66 was higher than that of Al2O3/UiO-66. Meanwhile, the oxidation of H2S over Al2O3/UiO-66 proceeded through a stepwise oxidation process, while over Fe2O3/UiO-66 it involved an oxidation–reduction process. The Raman spectra of fresh and used Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 were shown in Fig. S4. As illustrated in Fig. S4, the surface of Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 is comprised of OC-O, CC, C = CH, and OH functional groups [39,40]. In comparison to Al2O3/UiO-66, Fe2O3/UiO-66 exhibits a greater abundance of surface functional groups, which renders it more conducive to the adsorption and oxidation of H2S. Furthermore, the surface of the reacted Fe2O3/UiO-66 exhibited a greater consumption of reducing functional groups, indicating that a greater number of reducing surface functional groups were involved in the catalytic conversion of H2S and promoted the production of elemental S. 3.3 XPS characterization result over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 To investigate the difference in oxidation products between Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66, XPS measurements were conducted and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . As depicted in Fig. 4, the predominant active components in Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 were Fe2O3 and Al2O3, respectively. On the surface of used Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66, the content of Fe2O3 and Al2O3 decreased. It indicates that metal oxides are consumed in the oxidation process of H2S. For Fe2O3/UiO-66, the sulfur-containing products were sulfate and elemental sulfur, which coated the surface of Fe2O3 and prevented the leaching of Fe from the used catalyst. However, only sulfate appeared on the Al2O3/UiO-66. Furthermore, the lattice oxygen only exists on the surface of fresh Fe2O3/UiO-66. The surface oxygen content of used Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 decreased. Combined with the aforementioned results, the presence of surface oxygen and lattice oxygen facilitated the oxidation of H2S. The difference lies in the fact that the production of sulfate/SO2 is primarily attributed to the surface oxygen, while the production of elemental sulfur is primarily attributed to the lattice oxygen. The generation of sulfate occurs through the interaction between sulfur-containing compounds and metal oxides, resulting in the depletion of Fe2O3 and Al2O3. This result explains the reason for the formation of elemental sulfur only on the surface of Fe2O3/UiO-66. The product generation processes of H2S on Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 surfaces were as follows: H2S → HSO4 2− → SO2 → S for Fe2O3/UiO-66, and H2S → S2O4 2− → SO2 for Al2O3/UiO-66. 3.4 XRD characterization result over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 XRD characterization was used to investigate the possible sulfur-containing reaction products over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66. The characterization results are shown in Fig. 5 . As seen in Fig. 5, due to the low metal loading, no characteristic peaks of Fe2O3 and Al2O3 were observed on the surface of catalysts. On the surface of Fe2O3/UiO-66, SOx was first generated, followed by a reduction reaction to generate elemental S. It revealed the source of elemental S and possible conversion pathways. On the surface of Al2O3/UiO-66, no significant elemental S production was observed, but a significant amount of SOx was generated, which might be derived from the oxidation of S. In general, the selectivity of Fe2O3 and Al2O3 for the catalytic oxidation of H2S is moderate, with higher selectivity observed for V2O5, Mn2O3, and TiO2 [41,42]. Nevertheless, when compared to Fe2O3 and Al2O3, Fe2O3 exhibits greater oxidizability and yields a greater quantity of elemental S. Furthermore, Fe2O3 is capable of more effectively reducing high-valent sulfides to elemental S without the need for additional oxygen supplementation. Consequently, Fe2O3 exhibits a higher sulfur resistance and selectivity for elemental S than Al2O3, which was consistent with the XPS results. 3.5 CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD characterization result over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD were used to study the effect of surface acidity and alkalinity on adsorption and catalysis. The CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD curves are shown in Fig. 6 . As seen in Fig. 6, there are weak alkaline sites, strong alkaline sites, and weak acidic sites on the surface of UiO-66 simultaneously. The strong alkaline sites on the surfaces of Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 disappeared, and the strength and number of weak alkaline sites were enhanced after loading metal oxides. Fe2O3/UiO-66 exhibited stronger weak alkaline properties, which was conducive to the adsorption of H2S and product SO2. In addition, there were fewer weakly alkaline sites on the surface of Al2O3/UiO-66. After loading metal oxides, the strength of weak acidic sites was enhanced, but only the number of weak acidic sites on the surface of Al2O3/UiO-66 increased, indicating that weak acidic sites did not significantly promote the adsorption of H2S and SO2. Therefore, weak alkaline sites played a major role in the removal of H2S. 3.6 HAADF-STEM characterization and BET results over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 The dispersion of active components and the particle size of catalysts affected the removal efficiency of H2S. HAADF-STEM images and elemental maps of catalysts were shown in Fig. 7 . According to Fig. 7, Fe2O3 was evenly distributed on the surface of UiO-66, resulting in smaller particle sizes and less aggregation of Fe2O3/UiO-66 particles. It facilitates a more dispersed distribution of active sites on the carrier surface, thereby increasing the number of effective active sites. On the contrary, Al2O3 was densely distributed on the surface of UiO-66, and the formed Al2O3/UiO-66 was prone to aggregation. Although the Al element in Al2O3/UiO-66 possesses a higher density than Fe element in Fe2O3/UiO-66, it reduced the number of effective sites on the catalyst surface. Therefore, Fe2O3/UiO-66 provided more effective active sites, thereby further enhancing the adsorption and catalytic performance of the catalyst. The N2 adsorption-desorption curves and pore size distributions of UiO-66, Fe2O3/UiO-66, and Al2O3/UiO-66 are employed to assess the impact of metal oxides on the surface properties of UiO-66. The findings are presented in Fig. S4. The results of the pore characterization and specific surface area are presented in Table S1. As illustrated in Fig. S4, the samples UiO-66, Fe2O3/UiO-66, and Al2O3/UiO-66 exhibit the typical IV curves with H4 hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures in the samples [44,45]. The pore diameter distributions presented in Fig. S4c also corroborate the existence of a mesoporous structure. As indicated in Table S1, the microporous volume of UiO-66, Fe2O3/UiO-66, and Al2O3/UiO-66 was found to be 56.1 %, 55.9 %, and 58.3 %, respectively. In comparison to UiO-66, Fe2O3/UiO-66 displays a greater abundance of micropores and mesopores, which can be attributed to its high dispersibility. Nevertheless, Al2O3/UiO-66 displays a reduction in the number of micropores and mesopores, which can be attributed to the aggregation of particles. This is consistent with the SEM results. 3.7 In situ FTIR characterization result over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 To investigate the changes in surface species and the promoting effect of H2O during the desulfurization process, in situ FTIR experiments were proposed. The spectra are shown in Fig. 8 . As seen in Fig. 8 when water vapor was not introduced, H2S could not be fully catalyzed and oxidized after adsorption on the catalyst surface, resulting in the gradual accumulation of H2S on the catalyst surface. After introducing water vapor, H2S can adsorb onto the surface of the catalyst and undergo rapid oxidation. The involvement of H2O in the conversion process of H2S facilitates the conversion of low valent sulfur-containing species (1275–1350 cm−1, O-S-O) to high valent sulfur-containing species (1375–1425 cm−1, S = O), thereby accelerating the overall conversion rate [43]. Furthermore, the oxidation of H2S on the catalyst surface came from the action of surface oxygen and carbon-oxygen functional groups. The addition of water vapor can supplement the consumption of carbon-oxygen functional groups and promote the oxidation of H2S. There was a significant S-O vibration on the surface of Fe2O3/UiO-66, which can be attributed to the generation of sulfates and the adsorption of elemental S on the surface [43]. There was no S-O vibration on the surface of Al2O3/UiO-66, indicating that H2S was rapidly oxidized to SO2 and then migrated to the gas phase. Therefore, Fe2O3/UiO-66 exhibited higher selectivity for H2S oxidation. It was consistent with the XPS and XRD results. 3.8 Mechanism of H2S removal over Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 3.8.1 Competition between of H2S and H2O adsorption over Fe2O3/UiO-66 According to the experimental and characterization results mentioned above, both H2O and surface oxygen were found on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the competitive adsorption and adsorption sites of three gas molecules have been investigated using theoretical calculation methods. The optimal adsorption structure and adsorption energy are shown in Fig. S6 and Table 1 . As depicted in Fig. S6, the most stable adsorption sites for H2O, H2S, and O2 on the Fe2O3 surface are the top sites. The observed effect was attributed to the physical adsorption effect of Fe-O, Fe-S, and Fe-O-O. For Al2O3, the adsorption process was attributed to the physical adsorption effect of Al-O, Al-S, and Al-O-O-Al. The adsorption strength was O2 > H2O > H2S. It indicates that H2O and surface oxygen can affect the adsorption of H2S on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the adsorption strength of H2S on the Al2O3 surface was lower than that on the Fe2O3 surface. This suggests that Fe2O3 is more effective for adsorbing and removing H2S. This is consistent with the experimental results. Meanwhile, the O2 molecule occupied two Al-top adsorption sites on the Al2O3 surface, further hindering the adsorption and removal of H2S on the Al2O3 surface. 3.8.2 Selective catalytic oxidation of H2S over Fe2O3/UiO-66 According to the above experimental results, the oxidation products of H2S on the Fe2O3 surface include HSO4 2−, S, and SO2. Therefore, based on these products, this work proposes the following reaction pathway: H2S → HSO4 2− → SO2 → S. The detailed reaction pathway and reaction energy barrier are shown in Fig. 9 . The reaction intermediates (IM) and transition states (TS) are shown in Fig. S7. As depicted in Fig. S7, the conversion of H2S to SO2 involves both an oxidation process and a reduction process, whereas the conversion of SO2 to S only involves a reduction process. H2S and O2 molecules first adsorb onto the Fe2O3 surface to form a stable adsorption structure. At this time, O2 was fixed on the catalyst surface in the form of a Fe-O bond, and H2S adsorbed onto Fe2O3 through van der Waals forces. Under the influence of the Fe-O-O bond, the S atom in H2S forms an S-O-O bond with the O atom, resulting in the fixation of H2S on the catalyst's surface. This step required 32.35 kJ/mol of energy consumption, and it generated H2S-O-O (IM2). Next, two additional O2 molecules participate in the further oxidation of H2S on the surface, forming H2S-(OO)2 (IM4) and H2S-(OO)3 (IM6), respectively. As the S-O-O bond formed, the energy demand for the reaction gradually increased. After H2S-(OO)3 was generated, the S-O-O bond broke, and the S = O bonds formed through TS4 and TS5 with energy consumptions of 75.24 kJ/mol and 68.33 kJ/mol, respectively. Further, the last S-O-O bond broke, and the S-H bond also broke. With the transfer of H atoms and the formation of S-O-Fe bonds, HSO4 2− (IM10) emerged as a measurable intermediate. In the oxidation process of H2S (IM1→IM10), the formation of IM7 was identified as the rate-determining step, with a reaction energy barrier of 75.24 kJ/mol. Subsequently, HSO4 2− (IM10) participated in the reduction reaction. The S-OH bond in HSO4 2− broke, and the resulting - OH combined with Fe atoms to form Fe-OH bonds. After two S-OH bonds were broken, HSO4 2− was reduced to SO2. The Fe-OH species generated on the catalyst surface can enhance the adsorption of H2S, which is advantageous for the removal of H2S. In the reduction process of HSO4 2−, the rate-controlling step is the generation of HSO3 (IM11), which involves overcoming a reaction energy barrier of 69.32 kJ/mol. Next, SO2 was further reduced to S by H2S. The rate-controlling step and maximum reaction energy barrier in this process were determined by the fracture of the first S-O bond in SO2. Compared to the oxidation process of H2S, the subsequent two reduction processes require lower reaction energy barriers. Therefore, the production of SO2 and S was more likely to occur, resulting in higher levels of SO2 and S production. 3.8.3 Selective catalytic oxidation of H2S over Al2O3/UiO-66 According to the above experimental results, the oxidation products of H2S on the Al2O3 surface include S2O4 2− and SO2. Therefore, based on these products, this work proposes the following reaction pathway: H2S → S2O4 2− → SO2 → S. The detailed reaction pathway and reaction energy barrier are shown in Fig. 10 . The reaction intermediates (IM) and transition states (TS) are shown in Fig. S8. As seen in Fig. 10, the conversion of H2S to SO2 involved two oxidation processes. In contrast, the conversion of SO2 to S involved a reduction process. H2S and O2 molecules first adsorbed onto the Al2O3 surface to form a stable adsorption structure, IM15. At this time, O2 molecules break and form two Al-O bonds on the Al2O3 surface. Meanwhile, the S atom in H2S formed an S-O-Al bond with the O atom, and H2S was immobilized on the catalyst's surface. This step required 65.74 kJ/mol of energy consumption, and it generated H2S-O (IM16). Next, the S-H bond in H2S-O broke, and the H atom migrated to the Al-O bond, forming the Al-OH bond. With the participation of the second H2S molecule, the formation of (HS)2 O (IM19) was accompanied by the formation of HS-O bonds. Subsequently, two O2 molecules participate in the oxidation of (HS)2 O by cleaving O2 molecules and generating S-O-S bonds. As a result, S2O4 2− (IM24) was generated with a reaction energy barrier of 81.33 kJ/mol, which was attributed to the formation of (HS)2O3. Next, S2O4 2− (IM24) participated in the oxidation reaction. The H atom in S2O4 2− (IM24) migrated to the Al-O bond, resulting in the formation of H2O. Simultaneously, the SO-Al bond was broken, leading to the formation of SOO-SO2 (IM27). Subsequently, SOO-SO2 (IM27) was further decomposed into SO2 through the fracture of the S-O bond. The crucial step in the oxidation of S2O4 2− to SO2 is the formation of O-(SO)2 O (IM26) which has a reaction energy barrier of 132.19 kJ/mol. Next, SO2 is further reduced to S by H2S, which is similar to the reduction process of SO2 over Fe2O3. The maximum energy barrier for the reaction was 52.31 kJ/mol. Compared to the oxidation process of H2S to S2O4 2−, the subsequent oxidation process of S2O4 2− requires higher energy barriers for the reaction. It was indicated that the production of SO2 required a higher reaction temperature, which was consistent with the experimental results. Furthermore, the oxidation step of S2O4 2− limits the generation of SO2, which in turn restricts the reduction process of SO2, thereby hindering the production of S. Compared to Fe2O3 and Al2O3, the energy barriers for the oxidation reaction of H2S on the Fe2O3 surface and the reduction reaction of SO2 on the Fe2O3 surface were lower. Therefore, Fe2O3 could facilitate the oxidation and removal of H2S at lower reaction temperatures, while also generating elemental S. This validates the aforementioned experimental findings. 3.8.4 H2S removal mechanism According to experimental and computational results, the removal mechanism of H2S on Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 is shown in Fig. 11 . H2O and O2 competed with H2S for adsorption on both Fe2O3 and Al2O3. The oxidation mechanism of H2S over Fe2O3 is as follows: H2S → H2S-(OO) → H2S-(OO)2 → H2S-(OO)3 → HSO4 2− → HSO3 → SO2 → S = O → S. Meanwhile, the oxidation mechanism of H2S over Al2O3 is as follows: H2S → H2S-O → (HS)2 O → (HS)2O2 → (HS)2O3 → S2O4 2− → O-(SO)2 O → SOO-SO2 → SO2 → S = O → S. 4 Conclusion Fe2O3/UiO-66 showed a 100 % H2S removal rate at 150∼250 °C. The introduction of H2O extended the duration of 100 % H2S removal efficiency and reduced the production of SO2 at elevated reaction temperatures. The dithionates and bisulfates were the intermediate products of H2S oxidation over Al2O3/UiO-66 and Fe2O3/UiO-66, respectively. H2S oxidation over Al2O3/UiO-66 is a stepwise oxidation process, while it is an oxidation–reduction process over Fe2O3/UiO-66. H2O and surface oxygen could affect the adsorption of H2S on the catalyst surface. O2 molecules occupy two Al-top adsorption sites on the Al2O3 surface, which further hinders the adsorption and removal of H2S on the Al2O3 surface. The product generation processes of H2S on Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 surfaces were as follows: H2S → HSO4 2− → SO2 → S for Fe2O3/UiO-66, and H2S → S2O4 2− → SO2 for Al2O3/UiO-66. The further oxidation process of S2O4 2− and the cleavage of SOO-Fe bonds are the rate-determining steps for H2S removal over Al2O3 and Fe2O3, respectively. The present work provides a reference for the catalytic oxidation of H2S and sulfur selectivity under anoxic conditions. The generation of the product can be controlled by the pairing of Fe2O3 and Al2O3. Furthermore, the method can be employed for the deep fine removal of H2S under anoxic conditions, such as in natural gas desulfurization process. coredata.dc:description: This study used metal oxide-modified metal-organic frameworks to examine H2S catalytic oxidation selectivity. The findings revealed that the oxidation mechanisms and products differed between Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66. The dithionates were intermediate products of H2S oxidation on Al2O3/UiO-66, whereas the bisulfates were intermediate products on Fe2O3/UiO-66. Fe2O3/UiO-66 showed stronger surface oxidation activity than Al2O3/UiO-66. The formation of sulfate/SO2 was primarily attributable to surface oxygen, whereas elemental sulfur was primarily related to lattice oxygen. The product generation processes of H2S on Fe2O3/UiO-66 and Al2O3/UiO-66 surfaces were as follows: H2S → HSO4 2− → SO2 → S for Fe2O3/UiO-66, while H2S → S2O4 2− → SO2 for Al2O3/UiO-66. H2O and surface oxygen have the potential to alter H2S adsorption on the catalyst surface. For Fe2O3, the conversion of H2S to SO2 involves both an oxidation process and a reduction process. For Al2O3, the conversion of H2S to SO2 includes two oxidation processes. Due to the oxidation step of S2O4 2− limiting the generation of SO2, the reduction process of SO2 was also hindered, which in turn restricted the production of S over Al2O3. Fe2O3 can achieve the oxidation and removal of H2S at lower reaction temperatures, while also creating elemental S.
